newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: FEATURE - Irish graduates take on Silicon valley.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Irish graduates take on Silicon valley.

text.p: Two Dublin graduates have taken on America's Silicon Valley and developed a product that has made even U.S. computer experts sit up, take notice, and invest in their ideas.
Ireland's 3.6 million population could fit neatly into a corner of some U.S. state. So too could a tiny Irish company called Iona Technologies.

But that is not how things have happened for Iona, a developer of highly sophisticated systems software, and the brainchild of Chris Horn and Annrai O'Toole, while both were based in Trinity College, Dublin.
Fascinated by computer technology they dabbled with the idea of simplifying a method of allowing different computer systems to talk to each other.
Iona broke new ground when it developed a novel product, ORBIX, which provides a tool kit for developers enabling them to access and distribute information in diverse systems.
Their product provides the "communicative glue" to mesh different products, whether deemed "compatible" or not, to allow a user to pick and choose across systems.
"It is an age-old problem...people have been trying to connect different kinds of component software applications together," Horn, Iona's chief executive, told Reuters.
"As an analogy we are providing the pipework which allows you to build your plumbing systems. They can be simple or highly complex," he said.
Iona, still with just a handful of staff, laboriously prepared the paperwork for its Initial Public Offer (IPO) on Nasdaq.

Such was their product's success that when their zero-funded "campus start-up" of the 1980s was launched on New York's stock exchange in February 1997 it was snapped up and is now capitalised at almost $400 million.
FIRST MAJOR BREAK

The company got its first major break at a trade show in the United States in 1992, when Sun Microsystems Inc displayed keen interest in their product to the point that six months later Sun bought a 25 percent stake in Iona for just $600,000.
"Having Sun as an investor was a significant vote of approval from a major American player and probably gave us more leverage than a venture capitalist could have done at that time," Horn said.
Horn said Sun later offered to buy 100 percent of the company but after lengthy discussions it was decided that Iona would go it alone.
Response to its launch was such that its indicative launch price of $18 per share was ignored as the stock jumped to $22 right from the open.

Despite a downturn in the entire technology sector shortly after the launch, Iona reported a rise of 145 percent in total revenues to $9.1 million for the first quarter to March 30 when it released results on April 21.

"We had an excellent first quarter and beat all analysts' expectations. I am confident our business is going very well for us. It continues to grow well and we are looking forward to substantial growth in the future," Horn said.
Horn said he believes his company has an 18-month technology lead over the competition and is going to fight hard to keep it that way.
LOOKING FOR SUITABLE PARTNERS
In a sector where mergers and acquisitions are rife, Horn said Iona was on the lookout for suitable bed-fellows as a matter of course.
